intro: Dianthus caryophyllus var. consimilis, commonly known as the sweet William, is a flowering plant belonging to the Caryophyllaceae family. It is characterized by its showy, clustered flowers that range in color from white to deep red, often with a distinctive dark center. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring linear, grass-like leaves and a compact, bushy habit. Native to the Mediterranean region, it thrives in well-drained soil and full sun. It is widely cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and floral arrangements.
